docs.title: Welcome to MkDocs Graph Plugin
docs.text:
A Material for MkDocs plugin to generate an interactive graph visualization of your documentation.

  • Interactive Graph Visualization

    Creates a beautiful, interactive graph of your documentation.

    Learn more

  • Full-Site & Local Views

    Explore the entire documentation graph or view a local graph showing only connected pages.

    Learn more

  • Customizable

    Easily style the graph to match your theme with CSS variables.

    Learn more

  • Lightweight

    No heavy dependencies, just D3.js.

Get started in 5 minutes

This documentation is divided into four sections:

  • Tutorials — Learn how to install and use the plugin.
  • Explanation — Understand the concepts behind the plugin.
  • How it Works — A deep dive into the technical details.
  • How-to Guides — Step-by-step guides for common tasks.
  • Reference — Detailed information about the plugin's configuration.

docs.title: How it Works
docs.text: The MkDocs Network Graph Plugin integrates with the MkDocs build process to generate a graph of your documentation. This process involves a few key steps, from scanning your files to rendering the final visualization in the browser.

docs.title: The Build Process
docs.text:
The graph is generated dynamically every time you build your MkDocs site. Here is a high-level overview of the process:

graph TD
    A[MkDocs Build Starts] --> B{on_nav event};
    B --> C[Scan Documentation Files];
    C --> D[Build Graph Data];
    D --> E[Inject Graph into HTML];
    E --> F[Browser Renders Graph];

  1. on_nav Event: The plugin hooks into the on_nav event in the MkDocs build process. This event is triggered after the navigation has been built, but before the pages are rendered to HTML.

    Learn more about plugin events in the MkDocs documentation.

  2. Scan Documentation Files: The plugin iterates through all the Markdown files in your documentation to identify the pages and the links between them.

  3. Build Graph Data: Based on the scanned files, the plugin constructs a graph representation of your documentation. This includes a list of nodes (pages) and edges (links).

  4. Inject Graph into HTML: The graph data is then serialized to JSON and injected into the HTML of each page. The plugin also adds the necessary CSS and JavaScript files to render the graph.

  5. Browser Renders Graph: When a user visits a page, the browser executes the JavaScript, which renders the graph in the designated container.

docs.title: Why Use a Graph?
docs.text:
Traditional documentation is often structured as a linear sequence of pages. While this is suitable for some purposes, it can make it difficult to see the relationships between different pieces of information.

A graph visualization, on the other hand, allows you to see your documentation as a network of interconnected ideas. This has several advantages:

  • Improved Discoverability: By visualizing the connections between pages, you can more easily discover related content that you might not have found otherwise.
  • Better Understanding: Seeing the "big picture" can help you to understand the overall structure of your documentation and how different topics relate to one another.
  • Enhanced Navigation: The graph provides a powerful and intuitive way to navigate your documentation, allowing you to jump between related topics with ease.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Now that you understand the benefits of using a graph, get started with the plugin by following our Getting Started guide.

docs.title: Customization
docs.text:
You can customize the appearance of the graph by overriding the default CSS variables in your extra.css file.

Warning

Be careful when overriding CSS variables, as it can affect the entire look and feel of your site. It's recommended to test your changes thoroughly.

docs.title: CSS Variables
docs.text: Variable Description --md-graph-text-color The color of the node text. --md-graph-link-color The color of the links between nodes. --md-graph-node-color The color of the nodes. --md-graph-node-color--hover The color of a node when hovered. --md-graph-node-color--current The color of the current node.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
To change the color of the nodes and links, you could add the following to your extra.css file:

:root {
  --md-graph-node-color: #ff0000;
  --md-graph-link-color: #00ff00;
}

This would make the nodes red and the links green.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: After customizing the appearance of the graph, you might also want to configure the plugin's behavior.

docs.title: For Developers
docs.text: If you want to contribute to the development of this plugin, this guide will help you get started.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
Before you begin, make sure you have the following tools installed:

  • Python
  • uv

docs.title: Setting up the Development Environment
docs.text:
To get started, clone the repository and install the project in editable mode with its development dependencies:

uv pip install -e '.[dev]'

This command should be used initially to set up your environment and whenever you add new dependencies to pyproject.toml.

docs.title: Running Tests
docs.text:
This project uses pytest for testing. To run the full test suite, execute the following command from the project's root directory:

uv run pytest

docs.title: Code Style
docs.text:
This project uses Ruff for linting and code formatting. To check your code for errors, run:

uv run ruff check .

To automatically format your code, run:

uv run ruff format .

docs.title: Submitting Changes
docs.text:
Before you submit a pull request, please make sure you have:

  • Added your changes to the CHANGELOG.md file.
  • Run the tests and ensured they all pass.
  • Formatted your code with ruff.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: You can configure the plugin in your mkdocs.yml file.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Type Default Description name string "title" The name of the nodes in the graph (title or file_name). debug boolean false Enable debug logging in the terminal and browser console.

docs.title: name
docs.text:
This option controls how the nodes in the graph are named.

  • Type: string
  • Default: title
  • Options:
    • title: Use the title from the Markdown file's metadata. This is the recommended setting.
    • file_name: Use the name of the Markdown file. This can be useful if you have a lot of files with the same title.

docs.title: debug
docs.text:
This option enables detailed logging for debugging purposes.

  • Type: boolean
  • Default: false

When set to true, the plugin will output verbose logs to the terminal and the browser console, which can be useful for troubleshooting issues with graph generation or rendering.

docs.title: Example Configuration
docs.text:
Here is an example of a complete configuration:

plugins:
  - graph:
      name: "file_name"
      debug: true

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: This guide will walk you through the process of installing and configuring the MkDocs Network Graph Plugin.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Install the plugin using pip:

pip install mkdocs-network-graph-plugin

Important

This plugin is designed to work with the Material for MkDocs theme. While it may work with other themes, it is not guaranteed.

docs.title: Enabling the Plugin
docs.text:
To enable the plugin, add it to your mkdocs.yml:

plugins:
  - graph

That's it! A graph of your documentation will now be available in your site. By default, it will appear in the table of contents sidebar.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Now that you have the plugin up and running, you might want to:

  • Configure the plugin to change its behavior.
  • Customize the graph's appearance to match your theme.
